BLIST.TITLE: Books and 'zines
BLIST.ITEM:
Thinking in Javahttps://people.inf.elte.hu/delsaai/java/6Eckel%20-%20Thinking%20in%20Java%20(4th%202006)%20p1079.pdf
enPDF by BruceEckel: A free book to learn Java (Java 6).

Java Cookbookhttp://1.droppdf.com/files/8o1NF/oreilly-java-coobook-3rd-2014.pdf
enPDF by IanDarwin: A recipe book (Java 8).

X.T: JavaWorld
Java Magazine
Doug Leas
AmbySoft
Macadamian
Geotechnical Software Services
Google
OpenJDK
personal notes
2D animation with image-based paths
X.ST: Take the heavy coding out of fixed-object animation

ARTICLE.COMMENT: The paths of some sprites is recorded using some color encoding. Not a big deal…

X.T: Approaches to Mocking

ARTICLE.COMMENT: An introduction on using mocks (aka stubs) in Java: static mocks, dynamic mocks, AOP.

X.T: Java theory and practice: Coaxing J2EE out of the container
X.ST: Projects like Somnifugi JMS blur the boundary between J2EE and J2SE

ARTICLE.COMMENT: The standalone implementation of some J2EE components (JMS, JNDI) and using JMX.

X.T: Getting the Bugs Out: A Conversation With Bug Fixer Brian Harry

ARTICLE.COMMENT: The interview of a guy who killed hundreds of bugs in the JDK.

X.T: Developing iPhone Applications using Java

ARTICLE.COMMENT: The technical solution described here is too simplistic: the performance would be awful, you have to reimplement Cocoa in Java…

X.T: Project PlaySIM: Experimenting with Java Card™ 3 System Prog

ARTICLE.COMMENT: PlaySIM is a hardware prototyping platform: a daughter board for the SunSPOT platform is used to emulate a Java Card 3 SIM card.

X.T: Seven ways to get things started. Java EE Startup Classes with GlassFish and WebLogic

ARTICLE.COMMENT: How to perform some actions at the application startup or shutdown.

X.T: 5 things you didn't know about … everyday Java tools
X.ST: Java tools for everyday things, like parsing, timing, and sound

ARTICLE.COMMENT: Random stuff: StAX, ServiceLoader, Scanner, Timer, and JavaSound.

X.T: Have Java's Security Issues Gotten out of Hand

ARTICLE.COMMENT: Vulnerabilities are found over and over again in Oracle's JVM.

X.T: Transparent network acceleration for Java-based workloads in the cloud
X.ST: Introducing the Java Sockets over RDMA library

ARTICLE.COMMENT: A presentation of JSOR, how to use it, and how much it improves socket performance.

X.T: Build an application using microservices and CQRS
X.ST: Maximize the performance and scalability of your microservices-based apps

ARTICLE.COMMENT: Using Spring and Axon to implement an application having a CQRS architecure.

X.T: JVM Anatomy Quark #8: Local Variable Reachability

ARTICLE.COMMENT: Objects referenced in local variable may be collected before the end of the variable scope is reached.

X.T: How to Convert CSV to JSON in Java
X.ST: Convert CSV to JSON using Jackson. Use a POJO for conversion or a List & Map for intermediate storage.

ARTICLE.COMMENT: The title says all.

X.T: Deprecation of Object.finalize()

ARTICLE.COMMENT: Object.finalize() is obsoleted, but not planned for removal yet.

X.T: The State of Debugging in Java
X.ST: Debugging has come a long way from the jdb days. Here, we cover the variety of Java debuggers out there and some common practices devs use.

ARTICLE.COMMENT: A quick presentation of the tools that can be used to debug a system in production: jps, jinfo, jcmd, jmap, jhat, jstack, jstat, jdb.

X.T: Some factory examples.

ARTICLE.COMMENT: Creating a factory with plain Java, SPI, CDI and EJB.

X.T: 20 Examples of Using Java’s CompletableFuture

ARTICLE.COMMENT: A long list of simple examples with little explanation.

X.T: Java on Arm processors: Understanding AArch64 vs. x86
X.ST: Arm-based processors are increasingly popular and are in the news thanks to Apple’s latest notebooks and Oracle’s cloud services.

ARTICLE.COMMENT: A description of the current Java support on ARMv8 and a small performance benchmark to compare with Intel.

X.T: Using Java Flight Recorder With OpenJDK 11
X.ST: Want to learn how to use the Java Flight Recorder with OpenJDK 11? Check out this post to learn more about using the Java Flight Recorder and Java Mission Control.

ARTICLE.COMMENT: A presentation of Java Flight Recorder, but the author does not seem to master all the details.

X.T: SafeVarargs & Variable arguments in Java

ARTICLE.COMMENT: When to use @SafeVarargs.

X.T: Unit Test Your Architecture with ArchUnit
X.ST: Discover architectural defects at build time.

ARTICLE.COMMENT: A good overview of ArchUnit, a library to define some code rules and verify them as unit tests.

X.T: The Unsafe Class: Unsafe at Any Speed
X.ST: Just because you can break the rules, doesn’t mean you should break the rules—unless you have a good reason.

ARTICLE.COMMENT: The need for the features provided by sun.misc.Unsafe and how it is being replaced: MethodHandles, VarHandle, hidden classes, and the need for instantiating an object without calling its constructor.

X.T: Incompatibilities with JDK 15 CharSequence.isEmpty

ARTICLE.COMMENT: A description of some causes of source or binary incompatibilities and the particular case of CharSequence.isEmpty().

X.T: How Java 15 taught me to love virtual hands-on labs
X.ST: I worked through the three live hands-on labs that came with the latest Java release. You can, too.

ARTICLE.COMMENT: Some proselytism for Oracle hands on lab, but there is very little interesting information here.

X.T: A crash happened outside the Java Virtual Machine

ARTICLE.COMMENT: How to understand hs_err when a crash occured in native code.

X.T: OracleDevLive Preview | Trisha Gee on Learning New Java 16 Features with IntelliJ IDEA

ARTICLE.COMMENT: IntelliJ IDEA release planning vs. Java release planning, learning by reading code, the Java community.

X.T: Java still rocks the finance industry. Here’s why Java 16 makes it even better.
X.ST: High-speed trades? Quantitative analysis? The investment pays off.

ARTICLE.COMMENT: Some little information about finance IT and the role of Java in it.

X.T: All our support agents are busy, please hold.

ARTICLE.COMMENT: An advertisement for the service offer of Oracle: upgrade services, performance tuning services, and enterprise and third-party services.

X.T: Speaking the Java language without an accent
X.ST: Native fluency for nonnative programmers

ARTICLE.COMMENT: Some coding habits that C/C++ developers should modify in order to code in Java as everyone else.

X.T: Seven Low-Cost Ways to Improve Legacy Code

ARTICLE.COMMENT: Some simple Java coding rules to improve code maintenance.

X.T: For the Fun of It: Writing Your Own Text Editor, Part 1
X.ST: Using a layered design and iterative development, a line editor evolves into a text editor in this new article series.

ARTICLE.COMMENT: Some design details about a simple Java reimplementation of ed.

X.T: For the Fun of It: Writing Your Own Text Editor, Part 2
X.ST: Using Swing to write a GUI for the text editor

ARTICLE.COMMENT: The continuation of the previous article: creating a UI with Swing and testing.

X.T: The joy of writing command-line utilities, Part 1: Finding duplicate files
X.ST: Step-by-step creation of a small project that has practical utility

ARTICLE.COMMENT: The writing of a small application and an analysis of the taken small decisions.

X.T: The joy of writing command-line utilities, Part 2: The souped-up way to find duplicate files
X.ST: The brute-force method works—but a smarter algorithm improves performance by an order of magnitude.

ARTICLE.COMMENT: The continuation of the previous article.

X.T: The Java HotSpot Performance Engine: An In-Depth Look

ARTICLE.COMMENT: This describes the new technologies used by the HotSpot VM: adaptative compilation, inlining, garbage collection…

X.T: Java optimization techniques
X.ST: A practical guide for squeezing every drop of performance out of your Java apps

ARTICLE.COMMENT: This is obvious, but too often forgotten: before implementing low levels optimization, first check that your algorithm is not stupid.

X.T: Java theory and practice, Performance management -- do you have a plan?
X.ST: Knowing when to optimize is more important than knowing how to optimize

ARTICLE.COMMENT: The usual advice: performance must be managed as part of the development process.

X.T: Java performance monitoring, Part 1
X.ST: Java performance profiling with JConsole and VisualVM

ARTICLE.COMMENT: A very basic introduction to JConsole.

X.T: 5 things you didn't know about … Java performance monitoring, Part 2
X.ST: Java process monitoring with the JDK's built-in profilers

ARTICLE.COMMENT: jps, jstat, jstack, jmap, and jhat.

X.T: Java theory and practice: Urban performance legends
X.ST: Alligators in the garbage collector and other programming myths

ARTICLE.COMMENT: Some wrong ideas about JVM speed (synchronization and immutable classes are slow, final classes are fast) and some good general advice about performance.

X.T: Eye on performance: Micro performance benchmarking
X.ST: Byte offers a glimpse into application performance

ARTICLE.COMMENT: Instead of performing oversimplified flawed performance tests, looking at the generated bytecodes can sometimes reveal the pointlessness of some Java code tuning.

X.T: Java theory and practice: Garbage collection and performance
X.ST: Hints, tips, and myths about writing garbage collection-friendly classes

ARTICLE.COMMENT: Some old tricks to avoid the impact of garbage collection on performance have nowadays adverse effects.

X.T: Eye on performance: Tuning garbage collection in the HotSpot JVM
X.ST: Packing 100 megabytes of garbage into a 50 megabyte bag

ARTICLE.COMMENT: Tuning the garbage collector to lower its impact on performance.

X.T: Faster problem solving in Java with heuristic search
X.ST: Learn about a Java implementation of a popular search algorithm for artificial intelligence

ARTICLE.COMMENT: A description of A*, a heuristic search algorithm, in Java and its optimization by reducing memory consumption, using High Performance Primitive Collections, and recycling objects to avoid garbage collection.

X.T: Introduction to Java VisualVM

ARTICLE.COMMENT: The title says all.

X.T: Java Performance Optimization Tips: How to Avoid Common Pitfalls
X.ST: Since Java is one of the most widely used languages in development today, learning how to make your Java apps as performant as possible is a crucial skill.

ARTICLE.COMMENT: A short list of basic good pieces of advice.

X.T: A Guide to Java Profilers

ARTICLE.COMMENT: A short presentation of JProfiler, YourKit, Java VisualVM, and NetBeans Profiler.

X.T: Processing Large Files in Java

ARTICLE.COMMENT: The author describes some optimizations he did on a program parsing a big file.

X.T: On the Performance of User-Mode Threads and Coroutines

ARTICLE.COMMENT: The rational why loom focuses on increasing the number of concurrent transactions rather than reducing the cost of task switching.

X.T: Java theory and practice: Whose object is it, anyway?
X.ST: Garbage collection reduces the need to track object ownership -- but it doesn't eliminate it

ARTICLE.COMMENT: Use immutable objects or defensive copying, otherwise you will have to clearly document which classes own the objects to avoid tricky bugs.

X.T: Eye on performance: Referencing objects
X.ST: How you reference objects can seriously affect the garbage collector

ARTICLE.COMMENT: The authors explain how to fix unintentional object reference retention and that nulling reference is the wrong solution to a scoping problem.

X.T: Java theory and practice: A brief history of garbage collection
X.ST: How does garbage collection work?

ARTICLE.COMMENT: A short and clear description of the evolution of the garbage collection algorithms.

X.T: Java theory and practice: Garbage collection in the HotSpot JVM
X.ST: Generational and concurrent garbage collection

ARTICLE.COMMENT: The article describes the garbage collection algorithms implemented in 1.4 and what are their available tuning parameters.

X.T: Thanks for the memory
X.ST: Understanding how the JVM uses native memory on Windows and Linux

ARTICLE.COMMENT: After describing how the JVM is using native memory, Andrew Hall explains how to find what is eating it up and locating leaks.

X.T: The Essence of Caching - Ehcache

ARTICLE.COMMENT: Some general common information on caching and a presentation of Ehcache, an open source Java distributed cache.

X.T: From Java code to Java heap
X.ST: Understanding and optimizing your application's memory usage

ARTICLE.COMMENT: A detailed analysis of the memory used for storing an object, an array, or a collection.

X.T: Understanding the JDK’s New Superfast Garbage Collectors
X.ST: ZGC, Shenandoah, and improvements to G1 get developers closer than ever to pauseless Java.

ARTICLE.COMMENT: Some information about Shenandoah, ZGC, and G1 improvements.

X.T: An Introduction to ZGC: A Scalable and Experimental Low-Latency JVM Garbage Collector

ARTICLE.COMMENT: A short description of the Z Garbage Collector.

X.T: Java Tip 79: Interact with garbage collector to avoid memory leaks
X.ST: Use reference objects to prevent memory leaks in applications built on the MVC pattern

ARTICLE.COMMENT: Using WeakReferences to record listeners and a ReferenceQueue to remove them.

X.T: Guidelines for using the Java 2 reference classes
X.ST: Learn to effectively use SoftReference, WeakReference, and PhantomReference

ARTICLE.COMMENT: An introduction to SoftReference, WeakReference and PhantomReference.

X.T: Java theory and practice: Plugging memory leaks with weak references
X.ST: Weak references make it easy to express object lifecycle relationships

ARTICLE.COMMENT: An introduction to WeakReference and to WeakHashMap to store metadata about objects only for as long as they are effectively used.

X.T: Java theory and practice: Plugging memory leaks with soft references
X.ST: Soft references provide for quick-and-dirty caching

ARTICLE.COMMENT: Using SoftReferences to implement a simple cache whose memory will be reclaimed if the JVM needs memory.

X.T: Bitter Java - Chapter 6: Bitter Memories

ARTICLE.COMMENT: An introduction to Java memory leaks (unintentional object retention) and how to find and fix them.

X.T: Memory Leaks, Be Gone

ARTICLE.COMMENT: Some advertisement for the JRockit Memory Leak Detector.

X.T: How to Fix Memory Leaks in Java

ARTICLE.COMMENT: A good tutorial on how to analyze memory leaks.

X.T: Java shared classes
X.ST: Learn how to start your Java applications faster and with a smaller memory footprint

ARTICLE.COMMENT: Sharing classes between JVMs in order to reduce memory usage and startup time.

X.T: Taming Tiger: Virtual machine updates
X.ST: Changes designed to speed startup time and reduce memory requirements

ARTICLE.COMMENT: New command line options allow to handle JVM crashes, switching on Java Shared Archives and there are the usual garbage collector and thread scheduling changes…

X.T: Project Guest VM - A Java Platform implemented in Java and hosted on the Xen Hypervisor

ARTICLE.COMMENT: Using Maxine VM, a virtual machine written in Java, directly on top of Xen in order to get rid of the OS layer.

X.T: Command-line flags for the JVM
X.ST: Fine-tune JVM performance and the Java runtime

ARTICLE.COMMENT: Some JVM flags: -XX:+DisableExplicitGC, -XX:+HeapDumpOnOutOfMemoryError, -Xbootclasspath, -verbose, and -X.

X.T: A JVM Does That?

ARTICLE.COMMENT: The current status of JVMs: what works correctly, what does not work so correctly, and some suggestions of possible improvements.

X.T: Your next JVM: Panama, Valhalla, Metropolis by John Rose

ARTICLE.COMMENT: A wishlist for future JVMs: using Java instead of C++, fibers replacing threads, unification of classes and primitives…

X.T: Introduction to Java multitenancy
X.ST: Learn about a new feature for cloud systems in the IBM SDK Java Technology Edition, Version 7 Release 1

ARTICLE.COMMENT: IBM completed in Java 8 JVM to support running isolated applications in a single JVM instance.

X.T: Java multitenancy: Configuration options, tenant lifecycle, and isolation in action
X.ST: Dig deeper into the multitenancy implementation in the IBM SDK Java Technology Edition, Version 7 Release 1

ARTICLE.COMMENT: The java and javad command line options and some simple examples of using multitenancy.

X.T: Java programming dynamics, Part 1: Classes and class loading
X.ST: A look at classes and what goes on as they're loaded by a JVM

ARTICLE.COMMENT: A presentation of the class loaders, but more theoretical than applicable.

X.T: Cracking Java byte-code encryption
X.ST: Why Java obfuscation schemes based on byte-code encryption won't work

ARTICLE.COMMENT: The title says everything: just hack java.lang.ClassLoader.defineClass() in your JRE.

X.T: Class sharing in Eclipse OpenJ9
X.ST: Reduce your memory footprint and improve startup performance with the shared class feature

ARTICLE.COMMENT: A detailed introduction to OpenJ9's shared classes cache.

X.T: Java programming dynamics, Part 4: Class transformation with Javassist
X.ST: Using Javassist to transform methods in bytecode

ARTICLE.COMMENT: After a short presentation of Javassist, the author gives an example of its use by patching methods to measure method execution timings.

X.T: Java programming dynamics, Part 5: Transforming classes on-the-fly
X.ST: Learn how to modify classes as they're being loaded with Javassist

ARTICLE.COMMENT: A combination of byte code manipulation and class loading interception, in order to patch classes as they are loaded.

X.T: Using the ASM Toolkit for Bytecode Manipulation

ARTICLE.COMMENT: A presentation of ASM, a toolkit to parse, modify and generate bytecodes.

X.T: Create and Read J2SE 5.0 Annotations with the ASM Bytecode Toolkit

ARTICLE.COMMENT: This toolkit also handles annotations, enabling management of Java 1.5 annotations with earlier JREs.

X.T: CGLib: The Missing Manual

ARTICLE.COMMENT: A fast-paced overview of cglib.

X.T: JDK 11 and Proxies in a World Past sun.misc.Unsafe
X.ST: Java 11 is making changes to the Unsafe class. See what's being deprecated and how that's going to affect proxies for future projects.

ARTICLE.COMMENT: cglib will not be usable anymore, the author gives some short explanations on using Byte Buddy to replace it.

X.T: The New Obfuscation

ARTICLE.COMMENT: The interest of obfuscation and some obfuscating methods.

X.T: Java decompilers compared
X.ST: Our detailed examples of how 3 top decompilers handle an extensive test suite will help you determine which, if any, meet your needs

ARTICLE.COMMENT: A very basic comparison of DejaVu, Mocha, and WingDis.

X.T: Applets Reloaded: the New Java Plug-In

ARTICLE.COMMENT: This presentation of the new applet plugin implementation in Java 1.6 contains more demonstrations than technical information.

BLIST.TITLE: Diagnosing Java Code: I don't know why I read this series since most of these articles are (in my personal opinion) not clear, misleading and/or of little interest. But, at least, they provide some material to thing about.

X.T: Diagnosing Java Code: The Liar View bug pattern
X.ST: Be your GUI's best friend and expose the Liar View

ARTICLE.COMMENT: It is better to perform unit tests by checking the view rather than the model.

X.T: Bug patterns: An introduction
X.ST: Diagnosing and correcting recurring bug types in your Java programs

ARTICLE.COMMENT: Cut 'n paste code results into a program difficult to maintain, it is better to factorize the code

X.T: Diagnosing Java Code: The Dangling Composite bug pattern
X.ST: Squash one of the most common causes of the null-pointer exception

ARTICLE.COMMENT: Use dedicated special classes to indicate base cases (e.g. an empty linked list) instead of a null pointer.

X.T: Diagnosing Java Code: The Null Flag bug pattern
X.ST: Avoid using null pointers as flags for exceptions

ARTICLE.COMMENT: It is better to throw an exception that to return a null pointer in case of an error: developers using your code will less likely to accidentally forget to check the error condition.

X.T: Diagnosing Java code: The Double Descent bug pattern
X.ST: Beat recursive class-casting conceptual errors at the start

ARTICLE.COMMENT: In a recursive structure of objects of different classes (themselves forming a hierarchy), replace the use of casts by methods implemented in each subclasses.

X.T: Diagnosing Java Code: The Saboteur Data bug pattern
X.ST: Hidden data bombs may be the key to odd crashes

ARTICLE.COMMENT: The advice is obvious: check input data before storing or manipulating it.

X.T: Diagnosing Java Code: The Broken Dispatch bug pattern
X.ST: Argument upcasting cures inaccurate method invocation

ARTICLE.COMMENT: I agree with the bug, but its analysis and the proposed solution are wrong: the issue here is that when using polymorphism, all the overloaded methods should have the same semantic, having a constructor accepting raw data and another construction performing parsing is a basic mistake in the class design, a factory should have been used for the parsing instead of the second constructor.

X.T: Diagnosing Java Code: Improve the performance of your Java code
X.ST: Tail-recursive transformations can speed up your apps, but not all JVMs can perform the task

ARTICLE.COMMENT: The advice is obvious: if you care about performance, use loops instead of recursions. The remainder of this article is not clear and has no interest.

X.T: Double Dispatch in DDD

ARTICLE.COMMENT: How to dispatch method calls depending on the receiver and argument types, but the example is too simple to prove the value of the pattern.

X.T: Lisp and Java

ARTICLE.COMMENT: The author seems to discover the notion of functors…

X.T: Functional programming in the Java language
X.ST: Use closures and higher order functions to write modular Java code

ARTICLE.COMMENT: Yet another presentation of functors (here called closures).

X.T: Advanced Topics In Programming Languages: Closures For Java

ARTICLE.COMMENT: After explaining that closures do not really exist in current Java and why they would be useful, Gafter describes the current implementation proposition (planned to be integrated in Java 7) and gives some examples of using it.

X.T: Improve modularity with aspect-oriented programming
X.ST: AspectJ brings AOP to the Java language

ARTICLE.COMMENT: A presentation of AspectJ.

X.T: Use AOP to maintain legacy Java applications
X.ST: Techniques for dealing with complex and unfamiliar Java code

ARTICLE.COMMENT: The author explains how to use AOP to find where is called a given interface, to detect dead code, to test exception handling, to patch code… But this is only a poor man solution, it is better and faster to use the proper tools to analyze code.

X.T: Dependency injection with Guice
X.ST: Testable code with less boilerplate

ARTICLE.COMMENT: A presentation of Guice, but this one is probably too fast and the examples are too artificial to be really clear.

X.T: Google I/O 2009 - Big Modular Java with Guice

ARTICLE.COMMENT: A presentation of Guice: dependency injection (construtor, method, field), scopes (application, session, request), GWT/GIN and AOP.

X.T: Guide to Google Guice

ARTICLE.COMMENT: A short overview of Guice.

X.T: Java FTP client libraries reviewed
X.ST: Learn how the available libraries stack up against each other

ARTICLE.COMMENT: A benchmark of some FTP libraries and the issues of this protocol.

X.T: SMS-Powered Applications

ARTICLE.COMMENT: A good introduction of the SMPP API used to send and receive SMSes.

X.T: Generate PDF files from Java applications dynamically
X.ST: A step-by-step guide to iText, an open source library that makes PDF creation easy

ARTICLE.COMMENT: A short introduction to iText.

X.T: Web Swinging

ARTICLE.COMMENT: A presentation of SwingX-WS which can be used to generate HTTP requests and parse the answers by using a high level API.

X.T: Generating business documents using JasperReports with WebSphere
X.ST: Introduction to the Java API for JasperReports

ARTICLE.COMMENT: This presentation of JasperReports is not very clear.

X.T: Build better Web applications with Google Sitebricks
X.ST: Create a sample Java Web application using Maven, Sitebricks, and Guice

ARTICLE.COMMENT: A presentation of Sitebricks being used with Maven and Guice.

X.T: Introducing JobRunr: A distributed job scheduler for Java
X.ST: A quick tutorial on an open source library that leverages lambdas and Spring

ARTICLE.COMMENT: A short presentation of JobRunr: a distributed job scheduler with persistent storage.

X.T: Using the Jakarta Commons, Part 1

ARTICLE.COMMENT: A presentation of Command Line Interface, Discovery, Lang, Collections, FileUpload, HTTPClient and Net.

X.T: Using the Jakarta Commons, Part 2

ARTICLE.COMMENT: A presentation of Codec, Modeler, Betwist, Digester, Jelly and JXPath.

X.T: Using the Jakarta Commons, Part 3

ARTICLE.COMMENT: A presentation of BeanUtils, Logging, Pool and Validator.

X.T: JNA: Reading Windows Event Log entries in Java

ARTICLE.COMMENT: A description of EventLogIterator implementation to read the Windows event log.

X.T: JNA with Maven Quickstart

ARTICLE.COMMENT: A simple example of using JNA with Maven.

X.T: What’s new in Spring Framework 5
X.ST: How Spring 5 leverages Java 8’s functional syntax and a new, reactive programming model

ARTICLE.COMMENT: The title says all.

X.T: Eliminate Java verbosity the easy way

ARTICLE.COMMENT: An introduction to Lombok, a utility that generates toString(), equals(), hashCode(), getters, setters, synchronization, exception handling…

X.T: Using Lombok’s @Getter for Boolean Fields

ARTICLE.COMMENT: The title says all.

X.T: Read, recycle, and reuse: Reporting made easy with Excel, XML, and Java technologies, Part 1
X.ST: Read Excel files and write them to new files using Java and XML technologies

ARTICLE.COMMENT: After listing some Java libraries able to read/write Excel files, the author gives an example on using Apache's POI to parse an Excel file.

X.T: Read, recycle, and reuse: Reporting made easy with Excel, XML, and Java technologies, Part 2
X.ST: Convert between XML and Excel reporting formats

ARTICLE.COMMENT: The example continues, using XOM to write an XML file and POI to write an Excel file correctly formatted.

X.T: Business intelligence on the cheap with Apache Hadoop and Dojo, Part 1: Crunch your existing data using Apache Hadoop
X.ST: Feed a web-based reporting application

ARTICLE.COMMENT: How to use Hadoop to map, reduce and format the data.

X.T: Business intelligence on the cheap with Apache Hadoop and Dojo, Part 2: Create eye-catching, interactive reports using the Dojo toolkit
X.ST: Take advantage of Dojo charts

ARTICLE.COMMENT: Using Dojo to interactivley display the data prepared by Hadoop.

X.T: Struts

ARTICLE.COMMENT: This presentation of Struts is not clear.

X.T: Nine Features in Eclipse Collections 9.0
X.ST: CountBy, DistinctBy, Cartesian Product for primitive collections… and more.

ARTICLE.COMMENT: The title says all.

X.T: Code Duplication
X.ST: Duplicate code makes me itch, until I scratch it away.

ARTICLE.COMMENT: This is not about code duplication, but about presenting some patterns of collection initialisation, filtering and content short-circuit testing.

X.T: MicroProfile 1.3
X.ST: Discover five new APIs in Eclipse MicroProfile 1.3

ARTICLE.COMMENT: A short presentation of MicroProfile and the new features available in 1.3.

X.T: Hello, Coherence Community Edition: Creating cloud native stateful applications that scale, Part 1
X.ST: Use the open source Oracle Coherence Community Edition to create stateful applications that are as easy to scale, if not easier, than the stateless applications you are building today.

ARTICLE.COMMENT: The implementation of a CRUD REST API.

X.T: Hello, Coherence Community Edition, Part 2: Building the client
X.ST: How to develop React and JavaFX front-end clients that can work with a Coherence CE back-end application

ARTICLE.COMMENT: Implementing a Web client (using React) and a Java Client (using JavaFx).

X.T: JAR files revealed
X.ST: Explore the power of the JAR file format

ARTICLE.COMMENT: An overview of JAR capabilities: compression, executable JAR, sealing, extension mechanism, signing…

X.T: 5 things you didn't know about … JARs
X.ST: A Java Archive is more than just a bundle of classes

ARTICLE.COMMENT: Defining the main class, setting the classpath, storing JARs in lib/ext, classpath wildcard, and storing auxiliary files in the JAR.

X.T: Taming Tiger: Get environment variables and invoke subprocesses
X.ST: When deprecated doesn't mean forever

ARTICLE.COMMENT: The System.getenv() method and the ProcessBuilder class.

X.T: From Runtime.exec() to ProcessBuilder

ARTICLE.COMMENT: Using ProcessBuilder to fork a process.

X.T: 5 things you didn't know about … the Java Scripting API
X.ST: An easier way to do scripting on the Java platform

ARTICLE.COMMENT: Using jrunscript and ScriptEngine to launch scripts, bind objects to them, and compile them.

X.T: Advanced DAO programming
X.ST: Learn techniques for building better DAOs

ARTICLE.COMMENT: Some advice for implementing the Data Access Object design pattern: handling the transaction demarcations inside the DAO or leaving the client to handle them, using JDBC vs. JTA, logging and exception handling.

X.T: Java Database Connectivity
X.ST: Update your relationship to the JDBC API

ARTICLE.COMMENT: Getting the list of scalar functions, scrollable and updateable ResultSets, RowSets, and batch updates.
